RegExp Class

　The RegExp class is a class that handles regular expression patterns.
　Perl-compatible patterns can be specified for regular expression patterns.
　It is similar to the JavaScript RegExp class, but compatibility is low.

The constructor syntax is as follows:
new RegExp(<pattern string>, <flags string=''>);
　The pattern string is a regular expression pattern. Note that when writing a \ inside the pattern within a string literal, you must write it as \\.
　The flags string is a combination of the characters g and i.
　g is the global search flag. When this flag is set, the match, exec, and replace methods will process all parts of the string that match the pattern.
　The i flag makes the search case-insensitive for alphabetic characters.


Example:
    var re = new RegExp("[a-z]+[0-9]*", "gi");
    var re = new RegExp("\\.\\.\\."); // /\.\.\./ ( wanting to match ... )

Regular Expression Patterns

　Regular expression patterns can be specified between / and /.
　Please refer to Tokens.

compile

　The compile method sets a new regular expression pattern for the regular expression object.
　The arguments are the same as those specified in the RegExp class constructor.

test

　The test method returns whether the string specified in the argument matches the pattern.

Syntax : test(<string>)
　Returns true if it matches the pattern, and false if it does not.
　This method updates the values of each property of this object.

exec

　The exec method performs regular expression pattern matching on the string specified in the argument and returns an array containing the matching results.

Syntax : exec(<string>)
　If it does not match the pattern, the number of elements in the array will be 0.
　If it matches, element 0 (the first element) contains the entire matched part, and subsequent elements contain each matched sub-part (the parts specified by ( ) in the regular expression pattern).
　This method updates the values of each property of this object.

match

　The match method is identical to the exec method, except that it does not update the values of this object's properties.

Syntax : match(<string>)

replace

　The replace method performs string replacement and returns the string after the replacement has been made.

Syntax : replace(<target string>, <replacement string>)
　Matches against the target string, replaces the matched parts with the replacement string, and returns the string after the replacement.
　If a function is passed as the replacement string instead of a string, that function will be called for the replacement operation. The function takes one argument, an array object representing the matched part within the target string (refer to the exec method for details on this array). The matched part in the target string will be replaced by the string returned by the function.
　This method ignores the start property.

split

　The split method splits a string.

Syntax : split(<target string>, <(reserved)>, <ignore empty elements=false>)
　Returns an array object containing the results of the string split.
　Refer also to the split method of the Array Class.

matches

　The matches property is a read-only property representing an array containing each matched part.
　If it does not match the pattern, the number of elements in the array will be 0.
　If it matches, element 0 (the first element) contains the entire matched part, and subsequent elements contain each matched sub-part (the parts specified by ( ) in the regular expression pattern).

start

　A property representing the search start position in the string. The value can also be set.

index

　A read-only property representing the position of the first character of the matched part. Since 0 represents the beginning, if it is the first character of the target string, it will be 0.

lastIndex

　A read-only property representing the position of the character following the last character of the matched part. 0 represents the beginning.

input

　A read-only property representing the string being matched.

leftContext

　A read-only property representing the part of the target string to the left of the matched part.

rightContext

　A read-only property representing the part of the target string to the right of the matched part.

lastMatch

　Represents the matched string. Same as matches[0].

lastParen

　Returns the last part among the matched parts. Same as matches[matches.count-1].

RegExp.last

　The instance of the RegExp class for which the test or exec method was last executed.
Example : if(/pat(\d+)/.test(target)) { return RegExp.last.matches[1]; }

　The implementation of regular expression functionality uses Oniguruma by Mr. K.Kosako. We are grateful to him for publishing such a useful library.
